data.title: Everything You Need to Know About the Most Beautiful Country in the World Voted by Travellers
meta_keywords: Everything You Need to Know About the Most Beautiful Country in the World Voted by Travellers
data.meta_description: Read on to find out everything you need to know about travelling to the most beautiful country in the world.
data.text:
New Zealand, a land of unparalleled natural beauty, has been voted the most beautiful country in the world by travellers in a Rough Guides poll. Known for its breathtaking landscapes, vibrant culture, and adventurous spirit, New Zealand is a dream destination for many. Whether you’re seeking adrenaline-pumping activities, serene retreats, or cultural experiences, New Zealand has it all. In this comprehensive guide, we’ll take you through everything you need to know to make the most of your trip to this stunning country.

Top Things to See in New Zealand

New Zealand is home to an array of stunning sights. Here are some must-see attractions:

Milford Sound: Located in Fiordland National Park, Milford Sound is renowned for its dramatic cliffs, cascading waterfalls, and serene waters. It was once described as the ‘eighth wonder of the world’ by Rudyard Kipling. Take a boat cruise or kayak to experience the breathtaking scenery and spot wildlife like dolphins and seals.

Rotorua: Rotorua is famous for its geothermal activity and Maori culture. Visit Te Puia to see the Pohutu Geyser, enjoy a soak at the Polynesian Spa, and explore the Redwoods Whakarewarewa Forest's walking and biking trails.

Aoraki/Mount Cook: New Zealand's highest peak, Aoraki/Mount Cook offers stunning alpine scenery. Hike the Hooker Valley Track, stargaze in the Dark Sky Reserve, or take a scenic flight to view glaciers and the Southern Alps.

Waitomo Caves: These caves are known for their glowworms and limestone formations. Take a guided boat tour to see the glowworms or try black water rafting for a more adventurous experience. The Aranui Cave offers stunning stalactite and stalagmite formations.

Bay of Islands: The Bay of Islands features 144 islands with secluded beaches and rich marine life. Enjoy boat cruises, dolphin watching, and historical sites like the Waitangi Treaty Grounds. Russell, a charming town, offers a glimpse into early colonial history.

Hobbiton: Hobbiton, near Matamata, is the film set from "The Lord of the Rings" and "The Hobbit." Guided tours take you through the Shire, showcasing hobbit holes and the Green Dragon Inn, where you can enjoy a themed drink.

Top Things to Do in New Zealand

From adventure sports to relaxing activities, New Zealand caters to all interests:

Skydiving: Experience the thrill of skydiving over stunning landscapes in locations like Queenstown, Taupo, or the Bay of Islands.

Bungee Jumping: New Zealand is the birthplace of bungee jumping, with Queenstown's Kawarau Bridge offering an iconic jump.

Hiking: With countless trails, including the famous Tongariro Alpine Crossing, New Zealand is a hiker’s paradise.

Wine Tasting: Explore the vineyards of Marlborough, Hawke’s Bay, and Central Otago, known for their world-class wines.

Maori Cultural Experiences: Participate in a traditional Maori feast (hangi) and cultural performances to learn about the indigenous culture.

Wildlife Watching: Encounter unique wildlife such as kiwis, dolphins, and seals in their natural habitats.

Where to Stay in New Zealand?

New Zealand offers a wide range of accommodation options to suit every budget and preference:

Luxury Lodges: For a premium experience, stay at luxury lodges like Huka Lodge or Blanket Bay, which offer world-class amenities and stunning views.

Hotels and Resorts: Major cities and tourist destinations have a variety of hotels and resorts, such as the Braemar On Parliament Street and Hotel De Brett in Auckland or the Heritage in Queenstown, if you don’t mind the splurge.

B&Bs: Enjoy a more personal touch by staying at charming B&Bs scattered throughout the country.

Backpacker Hostels: Ideal for budget travellers, hostels like YHA and Base Backpackers provide affordable and sociable accommodation.

Holiday Parks and Campgrounds: For those who love the outdoors, holiday parks and campgrounds offer a cost-effective way to stay, often with cabins or sites for tents and caravans.

Dining in New Zealand

New Zealand’s culinary scene is diverse and delicious, reflecting its multicultural population:

Seafood: With its extensive coastline, New Zealand is famous for its fresh seafood. Try green-lipped mussels, crayfish, and bluff oysters.

Lamb: New Zealand lamb is renowned worldwide. Savour it in a variety of dishes, from roast lamb to lamb burgers.

Maori Cuisine: Experience traditional Maori food, such as a hangi meal, where meat and vegetables are slow cooked in an earth oven.

Wine and Cheese: Pair local wines with artisanal cheeses. Marlborough Sauvignon Blanc and Central Otago Pinot Noir are must-tries.

Cafés and Bistros: The café culture in New Zealand is thriving. Enjoy a flat white coffee and delectable pastries at local favourites like Wellington’s Fidel’s Café or Auckland’s Amano.

Best Time to Visit New Zealand

Choosing the right time to visit New Zealand depends on what you want to experience. The country boasts distinct seasons, each offering unique experiences.

Summer (December to February): Warm temperatures ranging from 20-30°C (68-86°F). Ideal for beach activities, hiking, and exploring the outdoors.

Autumn (March to May): Mild temperatures with stunning autumn foliage. Great for wine tours and scenic drives.

Winter (June to August): Cooler temperatures, especially in the South Island where they can drop below 0°C (32°F). Perfect for skiing and snowboarding.

Spring (September to November): Blossoming flowers and mild temperatures. Excellent for hiking, wildlife spotting, and enjoying nature.

Seasons and Climate

New Zealand’s climate varies across its regions, largely due to its diverse geography.

- North Island: Generally warmer than the South Island, with a subtropical climate in the north. Summers are warm, and winters are mild, making it a year-round destination.

- South Island: Known for its dramatic landscapes, the South Island experiences more extreme weather. Summers are warm, while winters can be cold, especially in the mountainous regions.

Visa Requirements for Indian Passport Holders

Indian passport holders need a visa to enter New Zealand. For tourism, you’ll need a Visitor Visa. Ensure your passport is valid for at least three months beyond your intended departure date from New Zealand. Apply online through the New Zealand Immigration website. Fill out the form accurately and upload the necessary documents. You can skip through the cumbersome process by simply approaching a travel agency specialising in Visa and they will make the process easier and hassle-free for you.

New Zealand, with its captivating landscapes, rich culture, and endless activities, truly deserves its title as the most beautiful country in the world. Whether you’re planning a thrilling adventure or a relaxing getaway, New Zealand promises an unforgettable experience. Start planning your trip to this magical destination and discover why travellers around the world have fallen in love with its beauty.
